body: Thanks!
Could you please review the changes I implemented on your behalf?
Thanks!

@dpolivaev can you squash up the commits and change the tabs in `AccessPermissionChecker` to spaces? If not, just let me know and I can take care of it.  In the future, it's helpful to create a separate branch for the PR to make it easier to rebase and avoid merge commits.

@blackdrag I would guess this is a candidate for 2_5_X and above, but maybe too much of a change for 2.4.12, though maybe not `breaking` in a code sense it could affect those running with security managers.  Do you agree?
agreed

@noamt; looks good to me functionality- and coverage-wise :)
I'm by no means an expert on the Groovy documentation-convention, but since the internal behavior for the right-argument has changed - shouldn't the Groovydoc match the new behavior?

Best regards,

Daniel
Care to elaborate?

@noamt; I've mulled over the implementation, and the right-argument evaluation and assignment could be replaced with a single null-safe expression `Boolean.TRUE.equals(right)` in the return statement :) #ZeroSideEffect

Great catch. Will do

> statement :) #ZeroSideEffect

Closing this in favor of PR #557 just in case someone is relying on the old behavior.
PR merged.
Done
Thanks.
No problem 😄
Thanks @dlehammer , I'll apply the changes

@blackdrag 
Where do you think would be a fitting place for the shorthand test cases? Doesn't feel like they should be `DefaultGroovyMethodsTest`

@noamt; if I remember correctly, @blackdrag suggested [OperatorsTest](https://github.com/apache/groovy/blob/183b8fbf0248a2dceffbba684e50c3c2c060e46c/src/spec/test/OperatorsTest.groovy) for the shorthand test-coverage.

Hello @paulk-asert , @blackdrag , @melix , groovy team, 
I'd like to suggest to integrate simple http client class into groovy language.
In attachment there is a generated javadoc and asciidoc documents.
Waiting for review or any comments.

[groovydoc_http.zip](https://github.com/apache/groovy/files/1068069/groovydoc_http.zip)

Actually, I am going to refine the Jira issues a little further. The current proposal doesn't push the relevant annotations to all the expected places for all cases that currently pass the grammar. This change may stand once I see what else needs to be done for the extra issues that I'll create or some aspects may move into or out of this issue.
@paulk-asert ping :-)

just two questions:
(a) why not from v8 to vm8 (vmX is the older one, so I was wondering)?
(b) why exclude v8 and vm8 in the build, if this is done to have only one of them?

I asked John to change the Java8 plugin package for consistency. We had used v5, v6, v7, and then vm8 (but so far only in 2.5.0-beta-1). I think 'vm8' is actually slightly more descriptive than 'v8' but doesn't match the convention now in many releases.

Since all tests containing vm8 in the core module were plugin related it seems okay to rename them too.

There are actually a few other spots in test names/packages using the string 'vm8' which we could also change to v8 but that can be done separately I think.
Thanks for your submission. I am hoping to get time to review shortly.
-1 from me unless it can be made compatible with the upcoming Java 9 native client http://download.java.net/java/jdk9/docs/api/java/net/http/HttpClient.html
@blackdrag Jochen, could you set aside some time to review the PR?

After some more thought I wonder if this (2.5+) would be the time to start a `org.apache.groovy.vmplugin` or `org.apache.groovy.internal.vmplugin` package and start with a `vm8` package under it establishing it as a new standard naming (i.e., followed soon by `vm9`)?

If there's interest in that I'll redo the PR, otherwise will merge this as is.

I think it would be confusing to have the plugins for different vm versions across different packages but I like your idea of doing a bit of a clean up. We are talking about a bunch of what should be internal classes, so I think we have some liberty to change but we'd probably want to do so with minimum disruption for anyone that might be sneaking in and using those "internal" classes.

I'd be inclined to leave the `org.codehaus.groovy.vmplugin` package as is but remove `vm8` and deprecate everything else. Then create an `org.apache.groovy.internal.vmplugin` package as you suggest and bring across a merged Java7 class in the `vm7` package which merges the current v5/v6/v7 classes (later versions taking priority). The `vm8` package would of course reappear in the new package.

We'd need to double check that didn't alter anything but I believe should be what we want for 2.5+. The tests can all stay in the `vmX` package variants.

I am leaning towards +1 but the two things I was planning to look into are:
1. Do we open ourselves up (any worse than now) to any security vulnerabilities if an AST transform could somehow inject a malicious controller. Possibly nothing to worry about, but I just haven't thought much about it yet.
1. Would it make sense to use the `LoggableTextifier` in the GroovyConsole. The answer might be no, I just haven't thought much about it yet.

In the end it does not matter all that much to me if we use v8 or vm8, just that it is only one of them ;) 

Should we go with org.apache.groovy.internal.vmplugin? We can do that. 

Frankly, some of the functionality in the plugins should probably move out of them again, since for example generics are really really part of all deployments of Groovy. But that is for a later PR.

@paulk-asert for (1) I think no; for (2) I would say that depends on our working process. I rarely investigate a bytecode issue in the groovyConsole, thus it would get me nothing there. But maybe Daniel does?

@danielsun1106 looks basically ok to me, but in the past I had only limited use for something like this. In some cases I did change the visitors to print the bytecode to a file, in other cases I added also LDC/POP combinations to add markers in the bytecode based on the part of ACG I was in at that moment. In other cases I was simply working with bytecode test cases or simple classes I compile.

@blackdrag I used to debug bytecode generation by logging. Sometimes I will reference the complete bytecode in the groovyConsole. BTW, I analyzed GROOVY-8085, GROOVY-8229 via `LoggableTextifier`, it is very useful. So I'd like to share it with others :)

Glad to know you and @paulk-asert does not reject it. I'll merge it later.
https://github.com/apache/groovy/commit/ab5defa3c1bfbf0c993394d11bb0f1e655283acc
PR #563 includes what I would think are "reasonably" compatible changes while moving to a new package and deprecating the old plugins.

The `leftShift` default method in the Java5 extension class was handled differently due to GROOVY-2987 so that is why the change was made to the existing `StringGroovyMethods.leftShift(StringBuilder..)` method.

Just a couple of things of note:

1. Since `GroovySystem.RUNNER_REGISTRY` is part of the public API the `Map` interface was retained for compatibility.
1. This PR also changes how the `TestNgRunner` is registered no longer requiring it to `Grab`'d in order to use it from the distribution since it will automatically be picked up from the classpath (see comments in [GROOVY-8196](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/GROOVY-8196).

Thanks for taking a look Paul.  As suggested I moved the `TestNgRunner` into a `org.apache.groovy.plugin.testng` package deprecating the old runner.  As I was doing that it also seemed like it would be a good idea to move the junit runners their own package so I moved them to `org.apache.groovy.plugin.junit`.  Also rebased to fix some merge conflicts.
This is intended for 2_4_X only. See also GROOVY-8234.
This is intended for 2_5_X+. See also GROOVY-8236.
Nice!!
If you get a chance to try it out (in particular with Grails) let me know. I haven't done as much testing as I would like. I'll check comments when I return from holidays.
Thank you.

Since the Junit runners didn't need to be public I "hid" them in a `DefaultRunners` class and since they are part of core am forgoing the IO to load them as services and adding them directly to the registry. If one or more of them is moved out in a future release they can go in a `org.apache.groovy.plugin.junit[3,4,?]` package similar to testng.
Thanks.

Just a minor comment, for checking whether the annotation exists I think `isAnnotationPresent(IgnoreDefaultEqualsAndToString.class)` reads a little better than `getAnnotation(IgnoreDefaultEqualsAndToString.class) != null`.

Thanks for the PR.  While I think it's generally good practice to make variable names more expressive, in this case I think `mv` and to a lesser degree `pexp` are commonly used in that particular class and in this case the renames make it a little more difficult to see what is actually changing.  Would you mind changing the var names back?

John, your suggestions look good. I'll be back from hols next week and can
check further then.


On 5 Jul. 2017 7:04 am, "John Wagenleitner" <notifications@github.com>
wrote:

> *@jwagenleitner* commented on this pull request.
>
> Overall looks good to me, but would be curious to know what @paulk-asert
> <https://github.com/paulk-asert> thinks.
>
> Also, just some general feedback. For the future I would recommend using a
> feature branch rather than making changes directly on master. Easier to
> avoid merge conflicts/commits that way.
> ------------------------------
>
> In src/main/org/codehaus/groovy/ast/tools/GeneralUtils.java
> <https://github.com/apache/groovy/pull/558#discussion_r125552693>:
>
> >      public static BinaryExpression cmpX(Expression lhv, Expression rhv) {
>          return new BinaryExpression(lhv, CMP, rhv);
>      }
>
> +    /**
> +     * Build a binary expression that compares two values
> +     * @param lhv expression for the value to compare from
> +     * @param rhv expression for the value value to compare to
> +     * @param reversed whether to use natural ordering or reversed natural ordering
> +     * @return the expression comparing two values
> +     */
> +    public static BinaryExpression cmpX(Expression lhv, Expression rhv, boolean reversed) {
> +        return (reversed) ? cmpXReversed(lhv, rhv) : cmpX(lhv, rhv);
>
> What about return (reversed) ? cmpX(rhv, lhv) : cmpX(lhv, rhv);? Could
> eliminate the need for the new cmpXReversed method.
> ------------------------------
>
> In src/main/org/codehaus/groovy/transform/SortableASTTransformation.java
> <https://github.com/apache/groovy/pull/558#discussion_r125553175>:
>
> > @@ -112,7 +113,7 @@ private static void implementComparable(ClassNode classNode) {
>          }
>      }
>
> -    private static Statement createCompareToMethodBody(List<PropertyNode> properties) {
> +    private static Statement createCompareToMethodBody(List<PropertyNode> properties, Boolean reversed) {
>
> boolean as the parameter type would be consistent with the other methods
> below.
> ------------------------------
>
> In src/main/groovy/transform/Sortable.java
> <https://github.com/apache/groovy/pull/558#discussion_r125553663>:
>
> > @@ -145,4 +170,9 @@
>       * Must not be used if 'includes' is used.
>       */
>      String[] excludes() default {};
> +
> +    /**
> +     * Set to true so that comparator uses reversed natural order.
> +     */
>
> Would be good to add @since 2.5.0
> ------------------------------
>
> In src/main/org/codehaus/groovy/transform/AbstractASTTransformation.java
> <https://github.com/apache/groovy/pull/558#discussion_r125554738>:
>
> > @@ -115,6 +115,14 @@ public int getMemberIntValue(AnnotationNode node, String name) {
>          return 0;
>      }
>
> +    public boolean getMemberBoolValue(AnnotationNode node, String name) {
>
> I think it's common to use memberHasValue for evaluating boolean
> attributes, so this new method is probably not needed.
> ------------------------------
>
> In src/main/org/codehaus/groovy/transform/SortableASTTransformation.java
> <https://github.com/apache/groovy/pull/558#discussion_r125555008>:
>
> > @@ -82,6 +82,7 @@ public void visit(ASTNode[] nodes, SourceUnit source) {
>      private void createSortable(AnnotationNode annotation, ClassNode classNode) {
>          List<String> includes = getMemberStringList(annotation, "includes");
>          List<String> excludes = getMemberStringList(annotation, "excludes");
> +        boolean reversed = getMemberBoolValue(annotation, "reversed");
>
> boolean reversed = memberHasValue(annotation, "reversed", true);
>

Thank you @jwagenleitner for the feedback, I applied your comments.
Updated the PR to consolidate the primitive-to-boolean conversion for both prim opts and static compilation and changed since tags to `3.0.0`.

This pull request originates from a [CloudBees](https://www.cloudbees.com/) employee. At CloudBees, we require that all pull requests be reviewed by other CloudBees employees before we seek to have the change accepted. If you want to learn more about our process please see [this explanation](https://github.com/reviewbybees/about#about-reviewbybees).
LGTM 🐝
Merged onto GROOVY_2_4_X
Updated PR to also include [GROOVY-8259 adding suppressed exceptions](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/GROOVY-8259).

My opinion is that something like this would be best provided as an external library and not included (from the start anyway) as part of Groovy itself or one of its subprojects.  There are already some nice http libraries such as [http-builder-ng](https://github.com/http-builder-ng/http-builder-ng) and [OkHttp](http://square.github.io/okhttp/) that are more complete and widely used.  Groovy has added some nice enhancements to the `URL` class for very basic fetching content, any more in my opinion is really best left to an outside library.
i see. ok, let's close this request.

>It appears it was originally placed there because at the time Java 6 was still used, but now 2.5.0 is 7+.

That was the reason (I think I merged the pull request.).

>Since 2.5.0 has not been officially released there may not be a need to deprecate or worry about binary compatibility for the withAutoCloseable method?

+1 no need to keep binary compatibility to a beta release.

Thanks for the PR, much appreciated.

Just a note, I relocated the newly added `GeneralUtils#cmpX(Expression,Expression,boolean)` method into the `SortableASTTransformation` class as a private helper method.  Given its limited use it didn't seem to warrant exposing it as a public method.  If/when other uses come up then it may make sense to move it back to a public method like `GeneralUtils`, but I think it's always good to err on the side of less visibility whenever possible.

This looks ok to me but @blackdrag 's [comment](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/GROOVY-8200?focusedCommentId=16023385&page=com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.issuetabpanels:comment-tabpanel#comment-16023385) does point out the asymmetry this may cause with other implementations of the methods on other objects as well as the already defined default methods (for example, `BitSet` and `Number`) which currently also throw an NPE, for example.

```groovy
Number n1 = 4
Number n2 = null

n1 |= n2 // NPE
// should it be equivalent of n1 | (n2 ?: 0)
```

But offhand I don't see a reason to not support this on `Boolean`, but would be curious to know what @blackdrag thinks.
+1 no need to keep binary compatibility with beta-1
@reviewbybees done
Proposed PR merged - thanks!

I totally understand the need for this but it does feel a bit like a hack to fix a slightly imperfect 'feature' of Groovy. I'd prefer to fix the underlying issue for upcoming releases of Groovy - and make a more generic way for Groovy to determine when to apply special formatting. But having said that, perhaps a short-term fix is needed for older versions anyway, so I am probably -0 on the concept as a whole but have no issue at all with your implementation as far as it goes as a short-term fix. And I realise that much time has gone by with the current situation without any kind of workaround.

I completely agree that a more generic mechanism would be better but that would require to wait for Groovy 3.0 (or later) that realistically wouldn't be released before 2019. 

For me it is perfectly fine to have this annotation declared as a temporary workaround that won't be supported in a future major release.
Merged. Thanks!
Proposed PR merged. Thanks.
Merged, thanks!
Thanks for the PR, merged parts of it along with @blackdrag 's suggested changes.
Thanks @jwagenleitner
LGTM
merged, thanks!
Thanks.
Thanks for the PR.  It would be helpful to have an issue we could associate this with, would you mind creating a JIRA ticket for this fix?  https://issues.apache.org/jira/projects/GROOVY

Opened https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/GROOVY-8294
Please let me know if you need additional information.
Travis failed because the tests took too long. Can someone tell me what to do? As I am not the first one with this problem if I take a look at the build history.

Try again or increase the timeout by modifying the .travis.yml, in which you will find a number 60.
BTW, the latter is not recommended because 60 min is long enough for normal build.
How can I try again? Increasing the timeout wouldn't be my first choice either, but I can't find a button in Travis to tell him to rerun.
Just push a new commit ;-)

Was there a Jira or email discussion about this leak? On face value the change seems OK but no test case is supplied so if we can't think of a suitable test we'd need to do some manual testing. 
Also, for api compatibility, we'd need to keep the no-arg 'makeCompileUnit()' method and mark as deprecated/include a warning in the javadoc.
Thanks!
Thanks!

Hello Paul,

because of the API change I wasn't sure if merging in 2.4 branch is the right way.
I'll close this PR and merge my change in 2.5 branch, keep the old 'makeCompileUnit()' method and mark it as deprecated. I'll try to create a test for that, but that's difficult because with building on ant project you don't recognize the resource leak. It is just a problem if you build multiple ant projects in a row within the same JVM (that's what we do actually).

Thanks for your advice and ... I'll be back ;)

Marcus
Does https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/GROOVY-7573 look related?  Also, just for future reference it's probably best to do the PR against master.

@paulk-asert The PR looks good. How about merging it?
P.S. It seems that I have not privilege to merge PR.
Merging isn't done through the github interface - that's an Apache workflow "feature". Instead just manually merge and amend (one of) the commit(s) to include wording like: "(closes #374)".
I'll merge it after running some checks.
Applied. Thanks. (Not backported to 2_4_X)

Hello @jwagenleitner, thanks for your link. This sounds absolutely like our error case.
I know that pushing against master is preferred, but in this case I wanted to bring the change live a little bit earlier, as Groovy 2.6 will release way later than 2.5.

Thanks for your advice.
